Anguilla.General Policy: Anguilla has no specific legislation to protect service dogs.

Antigua and Barbuda.General Policy: No specific legislation protecting service animals.

Argentina.General Policy: Service dogs must be allowed to accompany their owners into public spaces.

Aruba.General Policy: Aruba does not have legislation protecting service dogs.

Australia.General Policy: The rights of a person with an Assistance Dog are protected under Federal Law through the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (DDA 1992).

Austria.General Policy: Different types of assistance dogs are covered under Austrian legislation, including guide dogs, signaling dogs, and service dogs.

Bahamas.General Policy: Service animals are allowed access into food establishments.

Bangladesh.General Policy: Bangladesh does not have specific legislation protecting service dogs.

Barbados.General Policy: Barbados does not have legislation protecting service dogs. Assistance dogs must satisfy the same import conditions as pets.

Belgium.General Policy: Since 2014, it is unlawful in Belgium to refuse access to public places for certified assistance dogs.

Belize.General Policy: Belize does not have specific laws protecting service dogs.

Bermuda.General Policy: Service animals are required to meet the same conditions of entry as pet animals. No special concessions are made for service animals once in Bermuda.

Bolivia.General Policy: Bolivia does not appear to have specific legislation protecting service dogs.

Bonaire.General Policy: No specific legislation for service dogs.

Brazil.General Policy: Guide dogs are permitted on domestic flights with proof of vaccination.

Canada.General Policy: Each province has its own service animal laws, but there is no federal standard or certification.

Chile.General Policy: Assistance dogs are permitted to accompany their owners in public spaces and on public transportation.

China.General Policy: China may have additional restrictions on dogs.

Colombia.General Policy: Service animals are allowed in public spaces under Ley 1801, 2016.

Costa Rica.General Policy: Service animals are allowed in public spaces.

Cuba.General Policy: No specific legislation for service dogs.

Curaçao Island.General Policy: No specific legislation for service dogs.

United States.General Policy: US definition of a service dog: Service animals are defined as dogs that are individually trained to do work or perform tasks for people with disabilities. Note that: The work or task a dog has been trained to provide must be directly related to the person’s disability. Dogs whose sole function is to provide comfort or emotional support do not qualify as service animals under the ADA.
United States.Import Requirements: ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) (only in the US): Source: https://www.ada.gov/resources/service-animals-2010-requirements/
United States.Flight Staff Information:
Where can they go: Under the ADA, State and local governments, businesses, and nonprofit organizations that serve the public generally must allow service animals to accompany people with disabilities in all areas of the facility where the public is allowed to go.
What can staff ask about service dogs: When it is not obvious what service an animal provides, only limited inquiries are allowed. Staff may ask two questions: (1) is the dog a service animal required because of a disability, and (2) what work or task has the dog been trained to perform. Staff cannot ask about the person’s disability, require medical documentation, require a special identification card or training documentation for the dog, or ask that the dog demonstrate its ability to perform the work or task.
NOTE: In the United States, there is no special identification or registry for service animals.
